108.description:
Women* are welcome to join the 9th international Geochicas pre-conference event as a lead in to the conference icebreaker. Miriam Gonzalez, one of our esteemed keynote speakers, will be your host. Geochicas is a fantastic initiative - [find out more here](https://blog.mapillary.com/update/2019/05/28/putting-women-on-the-map-with-geochicas.html) and [follow on Twitter](https://twitter.com/geochicasosm). Two free drinks tickets at the door.

*anyone who perceives herself to be a woman
108.title: Geochicas take Wellington!

109.description: Come and meet your fellow attendees before the conference kicks off. We will be at the [Queens Wharf Ballroom](https://www.openstreetmap.org/directions?engine=graphhopper_foot&route=%3B-41.28365%2C174.778724#map=16/-41.2831/174.7780). Nibbles provided, two free drinks tickets at the door.
109.title: Conference icebreaker

201.description:
Join guest speaker *Dawn Hendrick* for a catered networking breakfast organised in conjunction with [Women in Spatial](https://www.surveyspatialnz.org/about/our_groups/women_in_spatial_surveying).

About Dawn:
Dawn started her career in the UK seismic exploration industry before emigrating to Australia in 1985. In 1991 she started her own mapping consultancy based in Brisbane and moved to Tasmania in 2010. Dawn’s clients have included local and state government departments and private and listed companies, mostly in the mining, environmental and engineering sectors. She now marks assignments for Spatial Science online courses at TafeNSW.

Dawn was awarded GISP-AP Certification in 2007 and again in 2013. She has also completed 33 years as a Topographic Engineer in the Army Reserve. She has presented papers at several conferences and regularly conducts training courses in geospatial software (MapInfo and QGIS). Dawn has previously held roles in the Surveying and Spatial Sciences Institute (SSSI) as a Queensland Regional Committee member & CPD Committee Chair; representative for the Spatial Information and Cartography Commission (SICC) and Women in Spatial and completed a four year stint as a member of the GISP-AP Certification Panel. Dawn is currently a member of the Geological Society of Australia; Australia and New Zealand Maps Society and the Mapping Sciences Institute of Australia.

Spaces are limited, [please reserve a ticket](https://ti.to/foss4g-oceania/foss4g-sotm-oceania-2019-conference/with/lsd79l4eeli).
201.title: Women in Spatial Breakfast

209.description:
A series of very short talks on a wide variety of topics. Here's a peak at what we've got lined up for you:

· Alex Lum - The World of Wikidata

· Andrew Harvey - Practical Mapping Tips

· Brent Wood - A new paradigm in web visualiation of species data

· Caitlin Adams - Lessons from a first brush with user experience design

· Chris Morgan - Agile Delivery in the Geospatial Industry at FrontierSI

· David Garcia - How to Map an Island in the Pacific

· Ewen Hill - Mapping in the International Year of Indigenous Languages

· Hamish Campbell - QGIS Geometry Generators

· Jessica Leiria Schattschneider - An open-source geospatial framework for beach litter monitoring

· Joeli Varo - A great giant of isolation in Papua New Guinea!

· Kamsin Raju - Challenges of Mapping Informal Settlements

· Michael Speth - High Performance Map Cache Generation

· ~~Merry Christmas~~ QGIS! - Nyall Dawson

· Richard Law - How I use Docker and Make for reproducible workflows

· Rose Phillips - Point Clouds, Pixels and Open Source Awesomeness – Investigating LiDAR Data

· Wing Ho - Offline Maps in the browser!
209.title: Lightning Talks

3032.description:
In putting together the first FOSS4G SotM Conference last year, there weren’t any specific goals around building a community, but we created something of a focal point. A light on the verandah that attracted a diverse group of open creatures together, and that gathering has been consistent only in how it continues to exceed expectations.

We want a lasting community, and that takes thought and effort. What works fine as ad-hoc chaos in the early stages, needs to be managed more systematically over time. It should ensure continuity and growth while embracing change and innovation. It needs to ensure that there is turnover so that there isn’t burnout, while encouraging lessons learnt to be passed along.

And so what we have in this panel session is a diverse group of individuals who, in their own ways, have been integral in the building of communities, and we’d like to discuss the building of this community and others with the audience here at FOSS4G SotM Oceania 2019.

Join moderator Alex Leith and panellists Lyzi Diamond, Bart De Lathouwer, Anne Harper and John Bryant.
3032.title: Panel: Building Communities

Edwin Liava'a.bio:
Edwin has a personal philosophy - "I innovate and provide solutions, not problems".

With over 20 years of experience working in the Pacific Islands region providing contextualized solutions and capacity building in ICT, his passion is driven by harnessing inter-cultural competencies. These competencies go well beyond technical knowledge and leadership qualities, because each Pacific Island has its own unique local context. Also important is the ability to possess a high level of cultural flexibility and tolerance to be neutral when it comes to discussions that might overlap from being politically correct to being in-correct.

Edwin believes that "The best idea should always win and we hire smart people to tell us what to do, not for us to tell them what to do."
Edwin Liava'a.name: Edwin Liava'a
Edwin Liava'a.shortBio: Edwin has over 20 years of experience working in the Pacific Islands region providing contextualized solutions and capacity building in ICT.
Edwin Liava'a.title: CEO

Dr. Kate Crawford.bio:
After successful careers as a pharmacist, a teacher (K-12), an academic, international researcher and software developer, Kate is now the director of a consultancy company Eviva Pty Ltd, an Honorary Principle Research Fellow at the University of Wollongong and an advisor to the Spatial Industry Business Association in Australia. She has experience in cross cultural settings including as a founder of the ANTEP program at Ernabella, South Australia and in Indigenous business development and program development in collaboration with communities.

Major projects include national programs to engage students and their parents in emerging Citizen Science projects, Community programs to connect older people with their community via digital technologies (Living Connect) in Illawarra region, Research with the University of Wollongong and Defence Science and Technology Organisation to enable more independent self-directed collaboration in the field (ARC Discovery Program). After much experience in early IT design and development, networked interactive communication technologies and related social innovation and problem solving, her current interest is the use of spatial technologies as tools in different cultures and to enable more sustainable practices for land and water management.
Dr. Kate Crawford.name: Dr. Kate Crawford
Dr. Kate Crawford.shortBio: After much experience in early IT design and development, networked interactive communication technologies and related social innovation and problem solving, her current interest is the use of spatial technologies as tools in different cultures and to enable more sustainable practices for land and water management.
Dr. Kate Crawford.title: Owner Director

Miriam Gonzalez.bio:
Miriam is co-founder of projects based in mobile applications and location intelligence technologies and the Geochicas initiative where she promotes more women participation and knowledge sharing in geospatial spaces.

For the past few years Miriam has been highly involved in promoting OpenStreetMap and Humanitarian OpenStreetMap (HOTOSM), increasing the participation of the community in Mexico and LatAm by giving workshops, conferences and coordinating efforts among key players in open data.

Currently she is involved in open data, autonomous vehicles, partnerships and data analysis initiatives.
Miriam Gonzalez.name: Miriam Gonzalez
Miriam Gonzalez.shortBio: Miriam is co-founder of projects based in mobile applications and location intelligence technologies and the Geochicas initiative.
Miriam Gonzalez.title: CEO / Co-Founder

Lyzi Diamond.bio:
Lyzi Diamond is a geographer/teacher/programmer living in New York City. In 2013 she co-founded Maptime, an organization of 80+ location-based community groups across the world focused on teaching each other about maps and geospatial technology.

She is currently a Developer Advocate at Glitch, a platform for building full-stack web applications in the browser. She cares a lot about map projections and probably wants to talk to you about most cool things!
Lyzi Diamond.name: Lyzi Diamond
Lyzi Diamond.shortBio: Lyzi Diamond is a geographer/teacher/programmer living in New York City. In 2013 she co-founded Maptime, an organization of 80+ location-based community groups across the world.
Lyzi Diamond.title: Developer Advocate
